SEASON 2

Cells Interlinked

Synthesis, refusal, creation

Master the paradox: build systems that judge humanity, then choose when and whether to use them.

CORE QUESTION

When the test itself is compromised, what remains?

Role

Season 2 synthesizes the technical and philosophical threads. You've built detection systems; now you confront the limits of detection itself. This season asks not "can we detect?" but "should we, and what happens when we can't?"

DURATION

14 weeks (August – November 2026)

PREREQUISITE

Season 1: Voight-Kampff (required)

ASSESSMENT

The Baseline Test — oral examination

CREDENTIAL

Certificate: More Human Than Human

Core Texts

Klara and the Sun

Kazuo Ishiguro, 2021

Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?

Philip K. Dick, 1968 (revisited)

Content Modules

01

Test-Aware Subjects

When the subject knows they're being tested, the test changes.

lecture
02

Corporate Optimization

How organizations game detection systems and what that reveals.

lecture
03

The Examiner's Doubt

When the tester can no longer trust the test.

dialogue
04

Detector Breakdown

When detection systems collapse under adversarial pressure.

technical
05

Trust Networks

Alternative architectures for establishing authenticity.

lecture
06

Process Over Product

Verifying how something was made, not what it is.

seminar
07

Refusal Protocols

The ethics and practice of declining to test or be tested.

seminar
08

Living with Uncertainty

When verification is impossible, what remains?

reflection

Capstone Project

Build an AI That Passes a Voight-Kampff Test

You will build a conversational AI system designed to pass one of the Voight-Kampff tests created by students in Season 1. This is not about deception — it's about understanding what makes a test passable, and what that reveals about the test itself.

Your capstone will be defended in the final examination before the faculty panel.

Key Activities

  • → Design a test that cannot be gamed
  • → Defend a position you disagree with
  • → Build an AI that passes a Voight-Kampff test from Season 1
  • → Write a refusal protocol for a real-world context

The Baseline Test

"Cells. Interlinked. Within cells interlinked."

The final examination is a 90-minute oral examination with a faculty panel. You will defend your capstone, argue both sides of an undecidable question, and articulate what you refuse to test or be tested on.

Pass

Full certificate

Revise

2-4 weeks additional work

Refuse

Honorable withdrawal

What You'll Gain

Technical Skills

  • • Advanced AI system design
  • • Adversarial testing methodologies
  • • Trust architecture design

Philosophical Grounding

  • • Ethics of verification systems
  • • Power dynamics in classification
  • • The limits of knowability

Professional Capabilities

  • • Defend complex positions orally
  • • Design ethical AI governance
  • • Navigate ambiguity professionally

Credential

  • • "More Human Than Human" Certificate
  • • Portfolio of original work
  • • Faculty letter (upon request)
